definitions.definition: a short piece of writing to help you remember something

examples.text: Please **make a note** of the dates.
She **made a mental note** *(= decided that she must remember)* to ask Alan about it.
**Note to self** *(= a mental instruction)*: book more holidays.
I've made a note of the book's title.
She kept detailed notes of her travels.
She made a mental note to call them in the morning.

phrases: make a mental note (of something/​to do something)

examples.text: Just a quick note to say thank you for a wonderful evening.
She left a note for Ben on the kitchen table.
He wrote a note to his parents saying he was leaving.
I left a note for Judith on her desk.
She left me a note to say my dinner was in the oven.
I saw you two passing notes during class.
Just a quick note to wish you luck.
He gave a handwritten note to the principal.

definitions.definition: information that you write down when somebody is speaking, or when you are reading a book, etc.

examples.text: He sat **taking notes** of everything that was said.
Can I borrow your **lecture notes**?

phrases: make a mental note (of something/​to do something)

definitions.definition: detailed information that is kept about a particular person, topic or situation

examples.text: Patients' **medical notes** have gone missing.
He **kept notes** on the birds, mammals, reptiles and plants he saw on walks.

definitions.definition: information about a performance, an actor’s career, a piece of music, etc. printed in a special book or on a record cover, etc.

examples.text: The booklet has full notes on each artist.
The catalogue contains detailed notes on each painting.
The sleeve notes include a short biography of the performers on this recording.

definitions.definition: a short comment on a word or passage in a book

examples.text: a new edition of ‘Hamlet’, with explanatory notes
See note 3, page 259.

definitions.labels: (British English)especially in British EnglishNorth American English usually

examples.text: a £5 note
We only exchange notes and traveller's cheques.
a thick wad of notes

definitions.definition: a single sound of a particular length and pitch (= how high or low a sound is), made by the voice or a musical instrument; the written or printed sign for a musical note

examples.text: He played the first few notes of the tune.
**high/low notes**
I played a lot of **wrong notes** because I was so nervous.
Some of the high notes were difficult for him to sing.
She's a bit wobbly on the top notes.

definitions.definition: a particular quality in something, for example in somebody’s voice or the atmosphere at an event; a comment on something with a particular quality

examples.text: There was a note of amusement in his voice.
It's good to finish **on a positive note**.
**On a more serious note** *(= speaking more seriously)*…
**On a slightly different note** *(= changing the subject slightly)*, let’s talk about…
The year ended on an optimistic note.
**As a side note**, the entire festival is free.
His remarks injected a note of levity into the proceedings.
I detected a faint note of weariness in his voice.
On a brighter note…
On a completely unrelated note…
The conference ended on an optimistic note.
There was a sad note in her voice.

definitions.definition: an official document with a particular purpose

examples.text: a sick note from your doctor
The buyer has to sign a delivery note as proof of receipt.
Students returning to school after absence must bring a note from their parents.

definitions.definition: an official letter from the representative of one government to another

examples.text: an exchange of diplomatic notes

definitions.definition: if two or more people compare notes, they each say what they think about the same event, situation, etc.

examples.text: We saw the play separately and compared notes afterwards.
Let's compare notes on our experiences.

definitions.definition: to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion

examples.text: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.
Unfortunately, the president struck the wrong note in his speech, ignoring the public mood.

definitions.definition: of importance or of great interest

examples.text: a scientist of note
The museum contains nothing of great note.

definitions.definition: to express feelings or opinions of a particular kind

examples.text: She sounded a note of warning in her speech.
The touch of cynicism struck a slightly sour note.
He sounded a cautionary note.
His opening remarks struck the right note.

definitions.definition: to pay attention to something and be sure to remember it

examples.text: Take note of what he says.
Under the new rules the penalty for illegal play is increased. Players take note.
He took careful note of the suspicious-looking man in the corner of the bar.
The frescoes are worthy of note.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in sense 6 of the noun and both verb senses): from Old French note (noun), noter (verb), from Latin nota ‘a mark’, notare ‘to mark’.
